ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: (Q 12)This class does not teach enough about modern leadership issues, rather focusing excessively onhierarchy. Trip planning also detracts from time that could be spent discussing actual leadership issues.
No matter what background you come from, this course is a must take.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: It was good to have field trips to be able to interact with people outside of F&ES.
The field trips.
The field trips introduced us to some interesting people with valuable insights.
Students coordinating and assigning responsibilities provided the first hand practice.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: My biggest suggestion for this course would be to focus more on a case study method and tie in the readings to class discussion. We did not discuss the readings at all. I think that it would be really helpful for students to bring in various case studies for the class to discuss and consider. Many of the examples of leadership mentioned in the class are outdated and having students bring some fresh material to discussion would be very helpful.

Chad devoted a class to hearing our feedback on what could be done to improve the course, which was good on his part. Mostly integrating the readings into the class discussion, and spending less class time preparing for the trips, and more time talking about leadership.
Class time could be used more effectively.
Two trips to DC and New York need proper coordination. Reduce the number of meetings.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: n/a
very relevant. Suggest working on the feedback from Q 15 for improvement

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course complement other courses.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I am required to take this as an MF
I was interested in taking a course on leadership. There aren't many offered at F&ES, so that was my motivation.
To improve my understanding of what "leadership" means in the context of the environmental problem solving.
To learn more about leadership and also improve on my leadership skills.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: No
Yes.
No
Yes, it did. It provided answers to almost all the questions that i had at the beginning of the course. Useful course. I am very happy that i took this.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I believe that the group work could have structured differently so that the work was completed efficiently and effectively. I was very frustrated with the group work.
The group work was an integral part of the course, but logistically, it did get complex at times.

Working in a group was a valuable exercise insofar as it allowed us to experience multiple personalities and work styles. The organization did get bogged down by inefficiency on a few occasions, which it might have been valuable to discuss and troubleshoot.
Learn from each other, group wisdom is always interesting and enriching than the individual perspective.However, coordination was a huge problem. When too many actors, it gets confusing

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: It is a low key class that fits into a spring second-year schedule pretty well. Chad is a nice person, and cares about the experience that students have in the class. There will likely be improvements from this year's class to next year.

Anyone, be it someone who worked prior to the FES or fresh from the undergraduate, is suggested to take this course. This helps in understanding actual field-level implementation. Taking this course will teach you on how to work in a team and more importantly, what are things to be done when you are in the leadership position. Authority and leadership are different. Mere possession of the authority will not make you a good leader.
